title: OpenPort
description:
Used to scan the ports of a host and determin which ports are open. Can be used to find the common uses of some ports. Works only on Windows. Tested on windows Vista.
Here is the source(for those who are scared of viruses):

import socket
s = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)
ports = {&#039;20&#039;: &#039;FTP data (File Transfer Protocol)&#039;, 
&#039;21&#039;: &#039;FTP (File Transfer Protocol)&#039; ,
&#039;22&#039; :&#039;SSH (Secure Shell)&#039; ,
&#039;23&#039; :&#039;Telnet&#039; ,
&#039;25&#039; :&#039;SMTP (Send Mail Transfer Protocol)&#039;, 
&#039;43&#039; :&#039;whois&#039; ,
&#039;53&#039;: &#039;DNS (Domain Name Service)&#039;, 
&#039;68&#039; :&#039;DHCP (Dynamic Host Control Protocol)&#039;, 
&#039;79&#039; :&#039;Finger&#039; ,
&#039;80&#039; :&#039;HTTP (HyperText Transfer Protocol)&#039;, 
&#039;110&#039;: &#039;POP3 (Post Office Protocol, version 3)&#039;, 
&#039;115&#039;: &#039;SFTP (Secure File Transfer Protocol)&#039; ,
&#039;119&#039; :&#039;NNTP (Network New Transfer Protocol)&#039; ,
&#039;123&#039; :&#039;NTP (Network Time Protocol)&#039; ,
&#039;137&#039; :&#039;NetBIOS-ns&#039; ,
&#039;138&#039; :&#039;NetBIOS-dgm&#039;,
&#039;139&#039;: &#039;NetBIOS&#039; ,
&#039;143&#039; :&#039;IMAP (Internet Message Access Protocol)&#039;, 
&#039;161&#039; :&#039;SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol)&#039;, 
&#039;194&#039; :&#039;IRC (Internet Relay Chat)&#039; ,
&#039;220&#039; :&#039;IMAP3 (Internet Message Access Protocol 3)&#039;, 
&#039;389&#039; :&#039;LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol)&#039;, 
&#039;443&#039; :&#039;SSL (Secure Socket Layer)&#039; ,
&#039;445&#039; :&#039;SMB (NetBIOS over TCP)&#039; ,
&#039;666&#039;: &#039;Doom&#039; ,
&#039;993&#039; :&#039;SIMAP (Secure Internet Message Access Protocol)&#039;, 
&#039;995&#039; :&#039;SPOP (Secure Post Office Protocol)&#039;,
&#039;1243&#039; :&#039;SubSeven (Trojan - security risk!)&#039;, 
&#039;1352&#039; :&#039;Lotus Notes&#039; ,
&#039;1433&#039; :&#039;Microsoft SQL Server&#039;, 
&#039;1494&#039; :&#039;Citrix ICA Protocol&#039; ,
&#039;1521&#039; :&#039;Oracle SQL&#039; ,
&#039;1604&#039; :&#039;Citrix ICA / Microsoft Terminal Server&#039;, 
&#039;2049&#039; :&#039;NFS (Network File System)&#039; ,
&#039;3306&#039; :&#039;mySQL&#039; ,
&#039;4000&#039; :&#039;ICQ&#039; ,
&#039;5010&#039; :&#039;Yahoo! Messenger&#039;, 
&#039;5190&#039; :&#039;AOL Instant Messenger&#039;, 
&#039;5632&#039; :&#039;PCAnywhere&#039; ,
&#039;5800&#039; :&#039;VNC&#039; ,
&#039;5900&#039; :&#039;VNC&#039; ,
&#039;6000&#039; :&#039;X Windowing System&#039;, 
&#039;6699&#039; :&#039;Napster&#039; ,
&#039;6776&#039; :&#039;SubSeven (Trojan - security risk!)&#039;, 
&#039;7070&#039; :&#039;RealServer / QuickTime&#039; ,
&#039;7778&#039; :&#039;Unreal&#039; ,
&#039;8080&#039; :&#039;HTTP&#039; ,
&#039;26000&#039; :&#039;Quake&#039;, 
&#039;27010&#039; :&#039;Half-Life&#039; }
def open_port(host=&#039;localhost&#039;):
    &#039;default is all, otherwise enter the port number you want to check&#039;
    port = 0
    while 1:
        try:
            s.connect((host, port))
            s.close()
            print &#039;Port:&#039;,port,&#039; At:&#039;, host,&#039; is open&#039;
            &#039;Port:&#039;,port,&#039; At:&#039;, host,&#039; is open&#039;
            print open_ports
        except:
            port = port + 1
            print &#039;Port:&#039;,port,&#039; At:&#039;, host,&#039; is not open&#039;

print &#039;Created By Erik Anderson\n==================================&#039;
print &#039;\n&#039;
print &#039;what would you like to do?\nEnter Scan to scan the ports of a host, and find\
to find the general use of a    port.&#039;
while 1:
    a = raw_input(&#039;What would you like to do?&#039;)
    if a == &#039;scan&#039;:
        b = raw_input(&#039;HostIP: &#039;)
        if b == &#039;cancel&#039;:
            pass
        else:
            open_port(host=b)
    elif a == &#039;find&#039;:
        b = raw_input(&#039;Port to find: &#039;)
        print ports[b]
    else:
        print &#039;Invalid Command&#039;

To use this source you need the python interpreter. You can download it at Python.org. Just paste the file into a text editer(not a word processor) and save the file whatever.py. The source should work on all OS&#039;s. Unix(this includes Macintosh)- check to make sure python is not installed first.

GL,
Erik Anderson
